email_body:
Dear Customer,
We noticed a recent transaction of $499.99 from your account. If this was not you, click here to verify and cancel the payment immediately: [suspicious-link.net/verify].
Sincerely,
Your Bank
task: Identify the red flags in this email.

explanations.Urgent language: Scammers often use urgent language to pressure you into acting quickly without thinking.
explanations.Suspicious domain: The link domain 'suspicious-link.net' is not an official bank domain. Legitimate banks use their own secure domains.
explanations.Generic greeting: Legitimate banks usually address you by name, not 'Dear Customer'.
explanations.Secure HTTPS connection: While HTTPS is important, it alone doesn't guarantee a legitimate site. Scammers can also use HTTPS.

profile_message: Hey, I saw you're interested in cybersecurity! I'm selling this amazing course for only $20. DM me if you're interested!
task: Identify the red flags in this profile/message.

explanations.Unsolicited offer: Receiving unexpected offers, especially from strangers, is a common scam tactic.
explanations.Too-good-to-be-true price: Quality cybersecurity courses typically cost much more. An unusually low price is suspicious.
explanations.Direct message request: Scammers prefer private messages to avoid public scrutiny or warnings from other users.
explanations.Positive reviews: The message doesn't mention any reviews. Legitimate businesses usually have public, verifiable reviews.

email_body:
Dear Valued Customer,
Due to a recent system upgrade, all users must reset their passwords. Please click the following link to create a new password: [reset-password-now.info].  This is a one-time process to ensure account security.
Thank you,
Account Security Team
task: Identify the red flags in this email.

explanations.Official signature: The signature is vague ('Account Security Team'). Legitimate emails usually include specific department and company names.
explanations.Suspicious domain: The domain 'reset-password-now.info' is suspicious. Legitimate password resets come from the company's official domain.
explanations.Urgent language: The 'Action Required' and mandatory reset requirements create false urgency to prompt hasty actions.
explanations.Generic greeting: Using 'Valued Customer' instead of your name is a red flag. Legitimate services usually use your registered name.

profile_message: I've got inside information on a new cryptocurrency that's about to explode! Invest now and get 10x returns in just one week! Limited spots available. Contact me ASAP for details!
task: Identify the red flags in this profile/message.

explanations.Unrealistic return claims: Promising 10x returns in one week is unrealistic. Legitimate investments don't guarantee such extreme short-term gains.
explanations.Pressure to act fast: Creating urgency with 'Limited spots' and 'ASAP' is a common scam tactic to prevent careful consideration.
explanations.Vague information about the investment: No specific details about the cryptocurrency or why it would increase in value are provided.
explanations.Promise of inside information: Claiming to have 'inside information' is a red flag as trading on such information is typically illegal.

email_subject: Delivery Problem: Your Package Cannot Be Delivered
email_body:
Dear Customer,
We were unable to deliver your package due to an incorrect address. Please click the link below to update your delivery information: [update-delivery-info.net]. A small fee may be required to reschedule delivery.
Sincerely,
Delivery Services
task: Identify the red flags in this email.

explanations.Unexpected delivery issue: If you haven't ordered anything, an unexpected delivery issue email is suspicious.
explanations.Request for payment to reschedule: Legitimate delivery services don't typically charge fees to correct an address.
explanations.Suspicious domain: The domain 'update-delivery-info.net' is not from a legitimate delivery service.
explanations.Clear tracking number: The email doesn't provide a tracking number, which legitimate delivery services typically include.

profile_message: Is your computer running slow? Click here for a FREE diagnostic scan that will fix all your problems! [free-scan.virus]
task: Identify the red flags in this profile/message.

explanations.Unsolicited technical support: Legitimate tech support doesn't randomly contact users offering help.
explanations.Promise to fix all problems: Claiming to fix all problems without diagnosis is unrealistic and suspicious.
explanations.Suspicious link domain: The domain ends in '.virus' which is not a legitimate top-level domain.
explanations.Free offer: While the offer being free isn't automatically suspicious, it's often used to lure victims into downloading malware.

email_body:
Dear User,
Your iCloud storage is almost full. Click here to upgrade your storage and avoid losing important files: [icloud-upgrade.ru].
Sincerely,
Apple Support
task: Identify the red flags in this email.

explanations.Generic greeting: Apple addresses users by their registered name, not 'Dear User'.
explanations.Suspicious domain: The '.ru' domain is suspicious. Apple only uses apple.com domains.
explanations.Threat of data loss: Creating fear of losing files is a manipulation tactic to prompt quick action.
explanations.Storage upgrade offer: While Apple does offer storage upgrades, they do so through the device settings, not email links.
